datasource: Heine, Heinrich, 1980, 'The Non-Bantu Languages of Kenya. Language and Dialect Atlas of Kenya', vol. 2. Berlin: Dietrich Reimer Verlag. pp. 173-219 [H80].
geodemoTXT: The Western Omo-Tana language, Elmolo was spoken in Kenya on the southeastern shore of Lake Turkana; it is not certain whether there are still any speakers .

arg.gloss: see (phonological changes in stem+suff; freq ‘see repeatedly’)

argis.gloss: show (from arg ‘see’. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 194)

dekay.gloss: hear (dekay ~ dey. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 195)

dis.gloss: build (“has lost more or less all distinctions of personal suffixes”)

eriv.gloss: lift up (phonological changes in stem+suff. eriv

esde.gloss: wait (esde ~ este. phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p. 195)

geet.gloss: bend (“characteristic of larger number of verbs that have retained part of the suffixial inflections but lost others”)

horr.gloss: chase away (retains complete set of pronominal suffixes)

kuredai.gloss: sing (one of verbs with no aspect distinction; serves also for perfect)

li.gloss: have (partly employs isolated pronouns of set B)

nuukis.gloss: suckle (from nuuk ‘suck’. phonological changes in stem+suff

yurg.gloss: push (phonological changes in stem+suff. deriv. p 195)

termclusters.label: elm-Verbmorph-Subject-Suffix
termclusters.note: H80pp.191-196 :: Note on general suffix verb pattern:Only a few verbs dispose of the full set of inflectional possibilities. Most verbs have merged various endings in one or theother way. (p. 192) Final-i/e verb pattern:“slightly divergent endings;final vowel changes to I in the subjunctive and the negative perfect,and to o in the negative imperfect”
